etymologies: Middle English faucon (originally denoting any diurnal bird of prey used in falconry): from Old French, from late Latin falco, from Latin falx, falc- ‘sickle’, or of Germanic origin and related to Dutch valk and German Falke. The -l- was added in the 15th century to conform with the Latin spelling

crossReferenceMarkers: Compare with hawk (sense 1 of the noun)
definitions: a bird of prey with long pointed wings and a notched beak, typically catching prey by diving on it from above.

notes.text: Family Falconidae, in particular the genus Falco: many species, including the peregrine, hobby, merlin, and kestrel

shortDefinitions: bird of prey with long pointed wings

definitions: a female falcon, especially a peregrine.
